title: Unit objects

content.raw:
First, this is cool!

I think we need a bit more context before we go forward. Can you make a quick document that explains the need for this and discusses the implementation? I think that it might be helpful for you to write up a short YTEP about this:

http://ytep.readthedocs.org/en/latest/

You could also just update the units YTEP:

http://ytep.readthedocs.org/en/latest/YTEPs/YTEP-0011.html

That will also help me to review so I can understand these changes. In general it's good to discuss implementation approaches before doing it so we can iterate on the design before you spend a bunch of time writing code.

My one bit of initial feedback is that I'm nervous about subclassing the `Unit` object. Why not just extend the `Unit` object? I worry that mixing `PeriodicUnit` and `Unit` will lead to more complexity, which is something I'm already a bit worried about.
content.html:
First, this is cool!

I think we need a bit more context before we go forward. Can you make a quick document that explains the need for this and discusses the implementation? I think that it might be helpful for you to write up a short YTEP about this:

http://ytep.readthedocs.org/en/latest/

You could also just update the units YTEP:

http://ytep.readthedocs.org/en/latest/YTEPs/YTEP-0011.html

That will also help me to review so I can understand these changes. In general it's good to discuss implementation approaches before doing it so we can iterate on the design before you spend a bunch of time writing code.

My one bit of initial feedback is that I'm nervous about subclassing the Unit object. Why not just extend the Unit object? I worry that mixing PeriodicUnit and Unit will lead to more complexity, which is something I'm already a bit worried about.

content.raw:
Oh, okay. Should http://yt-project.org/doc/developing/developing.html mention YTEPs?

I think the only real new functionality here is defining Units based on Units (the rest is just editing docstrings to match code or in one case editing code to match the docstring.) I can certainly put that in a YTEP. I'm going to actually read YTEP-0011 first, since I didn't know about it before. Um, if I do update YTEP-0011 (probably around "We construct a Unit object by..."), how do I indicate which parts are new so you don't have to comb through the whole thing? Or do you just use Blame?

If you don't mind every Unit carrying around a period that's None, that might work. I was thinking maybe a PeriodicUnit could ultimately get_internal_equivalent like a regular Unit can get_base_equivalent. That is, any periodic quantity with a definite lower bound and upper bound can be mapped to the range 0--2^64 and represented by a unint64, with overflow ignored, so that the periodicity is transparently handled behind the scenes. But I guess any Unit could have a get_internal_equivalent() that just returns get_base_equivalent() if the unit is not periodic.

I think the only real new functionality here is defining Units based on Units (the rest is just editing docstrings to match code or in one case editing code to match the docstring.) I can certainly put that in a YTEP. I'm going to actually read YTEP-0011 first, since I didn't know about it before. Um, if I do update YTEP-0011 (probably around "We construct a Unit object by..."), how do I indicate which parts are new so you don't have to comb through the whole thing? Or do you just use Blame?

If you don't mind every Unit carrying around a period that's None, that might work. I was thinking maybe a PeriodicUnit could ultimately get_internal_equivalent like a regular Unit can get_base_equivalent. That is, any periodic quantity with a definite lower bound and upper bound can be mapped to the range 0--2^64 and represented by a unint64, with overflow ignored, so that the periodicity is transparently handled behind the scenes. But I guess any Unit could have a get_internal_equivalent() that just returns get_base_equivalent() if the unit is not periodic.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout https://tests.yt-project.org/job/yt_testsuite_dev/1077/

You're right, that page should probably mention YTEPs.

The PR will show the diff.

I don't really understand your concern about the period, or why integer overflow matters. Seeing a YTEP describing this would help.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout https://tests.yt-project.org/job/yt_testsuite_dev/1082/
I'm with @ngoldbaum, I think this is great, but I also think that we should just make this part of the `Unit` object.
content.html: I'm with Nathan Goldbaum, I think this is great, but I also think that we should just make this part of the Unit object.

reason: For some unknown reason, this pull request refuses to follow my periodicUnit bookmark, so I'm recreating it.
description:
get_conversion_factor now actually returns an offset if applicable, matching the docstring. Have not added a test for this yet, that will be tested as part of testing YTArray conversions.

Some docstrings edited for clarity, in particular it should now be clear which direction Unit.base_offset points.

Two Units compare unequal if their base_offsets are unequal.

Units can now be defined relative to existing Units. test_create_Unit_from_Unit added.

PeriodicUnit represents periodic quantities such as radians, and test_PeriodicUnit tests this, although PeriodicUnit is not as of yet actually used for anything.
